site.name: Andrew Low House
site.desc: Andrew Low was an extremely wealthy cotton factor and father-in-law to Girl Scouts Founder Juliette Gordon Low, who inherited the house upon her husband’s death in 1905.
site.longDesc:
Time period: 1840s to present

Type of site: Domestic

History:

John Norris designed Andrew Low’s house in 1848. Andrew Low was an extremely wealthy cotton factor and father-in-law to Girl Scouts Founder Juliette Gordon Low, who inherited the house upon her husband’s death in 1905. After Mrs. Low’s 1927 death, The National Society of The Colonial Dames of America bought the home from the Gordon family and opened the house as a museum in 1950. Note: The Andrew Low House is a museum open to the public. Fees apply for entry and tours.

Archaeology:

In 2001 when Environmental Services, Inc. (ESI) investigated an area of the southwestern downspout in the dry “moat” that surrounds the Andrew Low house. The excavation was located in the south portion of the moat and uncovered a brick floor approximately one meter below the moat surface (Kratzer 2001). Archeologists also uncovered a portion of a brick arch.In 2005 Brockington and Associates conducted a ground penetrating radar (GPR) survey at the Andrew Low House in an effort to locate archeological features and identify existing drainage patterns (Weaver 2005).
site.evDesc: The dry "moat" surrounding the sides of the Andrew Low House
Detailed ironwork on the windows at the Andrew Low House

site.name: Battlefield Park
site.desc: The site of the bloodiest battle of the American Revolution.
site.longDesc:
Time period: American Revolution

Type of site: Military

History:

Battlefield Park is the site of the bloodiest battle of the American Revolution. You are standing where the Colonial and French Allies attacked the Spring Hill Redoubt on October 9, 1779. Fourteen redoubts, or small forts, connected by an abatis wall surrounded British-held Savannah during the American Revolution. The Allied casualties numbered approximately 800, while the British only 50. The Allies retreated in chaos, losing the battle but eventually winning the war. After the Revolutionary War, houses and small business sprung up including a distillery and meat-packing industries. In the 1830s, the area changed drastically again with the founding of the Central of Georgia Railroad.

Archaeology:

Along Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd rises a reconstructed Spring Hill Redoubt, about 3/4ths its original size. A few hundred feet down Louisville Road, a memorial marks the remains of the original Spring Hill Redoubt discovered in 2005 by Coastal Heritage Society archaeologists. Look for plaques around the park that give a detailed history of the battle and a column of stones commemorating the Allies’ casualties.
site.evDesc: Brass barrel band from a Charleville pistol.
The reconstructed Spring Hill Redoubt at the top of Battlefield Park.
Horizontal stones mark the outline of the original Spring Hill Redoubt. The redoubt extended into the current location of Louisville Road (in background).
A column of 800 stones memorialize the casualties of the 1779 Battle of Savannah.

site.name: Central of Georgia Railroad
site.desc: The Central Railroad and Banking Company was founded in 1836 by William Washington Gordon. The Savannah History Museum is original Passenger Depot.
site.longDesc:
Time period: 1830s-1960s

Type of site: Industrial

History:

The Central Railroad and Banking Company was founded in 1836 by William Washington Gordon (grandfather of Juliette Gordon Low, founder of the Girl Scouts). Central of Georgia Railway Savannah Shops and Terminal Facilities, as this area came to be known, is a National Historic Landmark. The brick building north of Battlefield Park is the original Passenger Depot and now houses a Visitor’s Center and the Savannah History Museum.

Archaeology:

The repair shops are partially restored and feature working steam and diesel engines. Many small archaeological projects have exposed older versions of the railroad over the year. For example, archaeologists have found the footprint of the first, smaller roundhouse where the rolling stock (correct name for a train car) was parked when undergoing minor repairs. The current roundhouse is the building closest to Battlefield Park.

The first transfer table, a mechanism for transporting rolling stock to the correct stall in the Carpentry Shop and Paint Shop, was also discovered archaeologically. Part of this transfer table is preserved outside of the Savannah Children’s Museum, which will be housed in the old Paint Shop.

Note: Today the repair shops are the Georgia State Railroad Museum run by Coastal Heritage Society and do require an entry fee.
site.evDesc: The remains of the original Central of Georgia Railway transfer table (facing west). The Carpentry Shop is to the left outside of the frame.
The remains of the original Central of Georgia Railway transfer table (facing east).
The Passenger Depot for the Central of Georgia Railroad seen from the Louisville Road side. The two-story portion held offices, while trains pulled into the back of the building (foreground).
The roundhouse had many bays for quick repairs to rolling stock (train cars). The smokestack from the Blacksmith’s Shop can be seen in the background.

site.name: Clusky Embankment Stores
site.desc: Named after architect Charles B. Cluskey, who designed a retaining wall four brick arched vaults for storage.
site.longDesc:
Time period: 1840 to present

Type of site: Industrial

History:

The Cluskey Embankment Stores are named after architect Charles B. Cluskey, who designed a retaining wall four brick arched vaults for storage. The four open Cluskey Embankment Stores were used for parking until historical interest was sparked. A detailed history of the embankments stores is available here.

Archaeology:

Researchers do not know how the embankments stores were used, so Georgia Southern University archaeologists are currently excavating (Fall 2013).
site.evDesc: Visitors try their hand at screening for artifacts at a Public Day.
A Georgia Southern University archaeologist digs a unit at the entrance to the embankment stores while visitors watch.
The interior of a vault.
One of the vaults was sealed.
The Cluskey Embankment Stores sit directly east of City Hall.

site.name: Colonial Cemetery
site.desc: The second major public cemetery of Savannah established in 1750
site.longDesc:
Time period: mid-1700s to present

Type of site: Cemetery

History:

Savannah’s first public burying ground was located northwest of Colonial Park Cemetery. When town expansion and population growth dictated, the second major public cemetery in Savannah, Colonial Park Cemetery, was established in 1750. The cemetery was enlarged several times and closed in 1853. Laurel Grove Cemetery was opened to replace the old Colonial Cemetery.

The greenspace directly south of Colonial Park cemetery houses, stables, outhouses, and storage buildings in the 1800s. It was designated as “city lot” and “City pound” on historic maps. In 1896 it was officially added to Colonial Park and named Davant Park.

Archaeology:

In 1999, Chicora Foundation archaeologists mapped the cemetery- both existing tombs and gravestones as well as unmarked graves. Unmarked graves were located with a penetrometer survey (a penetrometer measures soil compaction). The survey confirmed historical accounts that the cemetery was filled to overflowing. Archaeologists found an astonishing 8,678 unmarked graves in addition to the 560 marked graves. Nearly every grave was disturbed in some way as fresh graves were partially dug into previous ones. Contrary to other reports, no mass grave was found.

Also contrary to local legend, no evidence was found that Civil War soldiers had ever camped or stabled horses in Colonial Cemetery. Archaeologists did find many late-1800s artifacts from citizens enjoying the park including lamp parts, soda and alcohol glass bottles, toys, pipes, and shell casings and bullets. Coins and beads suggest the possibility of voodoo practices in the park. Few clothing artifacts or elaborate coffin hardware was found, so the burials were probably simple. People were likely buried in shrouds and simple wood coffins.

In 2008, Coastal Heritage Society archaeologists conducted a ground penetrating radar survey of the southeastern portion of the cemetery and part of Davant Park. They found a large linear anomaly running northeast/southwest, that seemed to coincide with Revolutionary War fortification ditches seen on historic maps. GPR also showed that there were no graves in Davant Park, allowing for excavation. A small excavation revealed two lead balls (bullets of the 1700s) early in the excavation, raising hopes. Unfortunately, they did not find a Revolutionary War trench, however, they did find evidence of a privy dating roughly to 1790s-1870s. The excavation unit was only a small test, and the soil layers suggest that the battlefield landscape is approximately 63-102 cm below the present ground surface. Future archaeologists will probably have more success in this area.

site.name: CSS Georgia
site.desc: The second major public cemetery of Savannah established in 1750
site.longDesc:
Time period: Civil War

Type of site: Military

History:

The CSS Georgia was built at Harding’s Shipyard on Savannah’s eastern edge. Built with money raised by the Ladies Gunboat Association, the CSS Georgia was floating opposite Fort Jackson by late October 1862. The vessel was one of the new ironclads, ships with a low profile, shallow draught, and protective iron plating over every inch that rose above the water. While plate iron was the preferred material for ironcladding, none was available for the Georgia, so local railroad tracks were interlocked over the surface of the vessel.

There is very little historical information about the design and construction of the CSS Georgia, which makes the archaeological evidence invaluable. Reports vary the vessel’s length between 150 and 250 feet. We also know the Georgia was seriously underpowered and had a top speed of two knots under full steam. This was inadequate to even fight the Savannah River tides and currents. So the ship was anchored off Fort Jackson as a floating battery with guns aimed downstream. The engine ran continuously to bail water because the Georgia leaked terribly. As Union General Sherman’s forces approached Savannah, the Georgia was scuttled and sunk on December 20, 1864.

In 1868, Henry Welles dynamited the ship, and 80 tons of iron was recovered and sold through a contract with the Treasury Department. The Georgia was forgotten again until 1968 when dredge operations “rediscovered” the vessel.

Archaeology:

Texas A&M University conducted an archaeological and engineering assessment in 1979, after four separate dredging operations had impacted the Georgia. They found a site 300 by 150 feet that was elevated seven to nine feet above the river bottom. Sections of armor plate, hull, and deck areas appeared intact, and the site had good artifact preservation. Two cannons were removed: a 32-pounder reworked as a rifled gun and a 24-pounder howitzer. Brooke projectiles, percussion fuses, and spherical shot were also recovered and preserved. Many of these objects are now on display at the Savannah History Museum.

A second site assessment was conducted in 2003 because of proposed harbor deepening and dredging activities that will destroy the site. This survey found the remains are very limited: two large and one small section of iron casemate, a propeller and shaft, three cannon, a possible boiler, and miscellaneous artifacts. The lower hull is entirely gone. Dredging operations have cut into the site, removing the surrounding sediments that protected the vessel.

Based on this latest data, archaeologists estimate the CSS Georgia was 120 by 44 feet with an unknown type of hull, but likely similar to the CSS Louisiana, CSS Jackson, or CSS Neuse. The Georgia probably had six cannons: two cannons have been recovered, three are mapped near the wreck, leaving one more to be discovered. Archaeologists are recommending a full archaeological excavation and data recovery.
site.evDesc: Ironstone serving bowl recovered from the CSS Georgia, on display at the Savannah History Museum

Artifacts recovered from the CSS Georgia in 1980, clockwise from top left: Carpenter’s adze; bearing plate, threaded bolt, and nut from a vessel timber; iron spike and cap (not conserved); iron leg shackles used to punish crew.
The view from Old Fort Jackson upriver towards Savannah. The CSS Georgia lies on the riverbed just northwest of the fort.

site.name: Emmet Park
site.desc: The site of Fort Prevost and Fort Wayne due to strategic position over the Savannah River
site.longDesc:
Site: Fort Prevost, Fort Wayne, and Trustee’s Garden

Time period: 1100 BC to 500 AD, 1733 to late 1800s

Type of site: Military, Native American

History:

A series of forts sat on the high bluff overlooking the Savannah River at the northeastern corner of town, which was an excellent strategic location. As early as 1734, a 12 gun battery and two block houses each with four guns were built. The fortification was greatly expanded by the British from 1779 to 1782 and renamed Fort Prevost, after the British General Augustine Prevost. After the American Revolution, the new United States resurrected the area as Fort Wayne.

Immediately south of the fortifications was the Trustee’s Garden. This was an experimental garden area dating the colony’s earliest days. Mulberry trees for silk worms were grown. Other crops include rice, olives, peaches, grapes, cotton, indigo, flax (for linen), and hemp. The gardens were closed in 1748 when the silk crop was deemed unsuccessful.

Archaeology:

At the eastern end of Emmet Park, Coastal Heritage Society archaeologists found a large, wooden-floored trench through ground-penetrating radar and excavation. The trench measured 33 by 10 feet and contained artifacts such as a brass percussion cap, a brass shotgun shell casing, clay pipes, nails, and late-1700s era pottery. Only part of the trench was excavated, leaving most of this feature preserved for future archaeologists. The feature might be gun emplacement or other military construction created during the American Revolution, the War of 1812, and maybe even the Civil War. More excavation might be able to better date the trench, which was probably filled in when the city built Factors’ Walk (ca. 1854-1869).

The park also has a Native American site, represented by oyster shell and Deptford check stamped, cordmarked, and plain pottery.
site.evDesc: Small shovel test pits help us find archaeological sites.
Close-up of artifacts in the screen from digging a shovel test pit. The oyster shell was left by Native Americans living here.

site.name: Fahm Street
site.desc: The extension of Savannah's borders that came to house industrial expansion of the Central Railroad of Georgia.
site.longDesc:
Time period: Late 1700s to 1900s

Type of site: Domestic, Industrial

History:

The City of Savannah wanted to extend Fahm Street, which then ended at Hull Street (now Turner Boulevard). Since the City was using federal funding, the National Historic Preservation Act required that the federal funding agency (in this case the Department of Housing and Urban Development) and City protect the National Historic Landmark District.

In the late eighteenth century and early nineteenth century, this area of Savannah was “New Leeds”, an early community on the western side of Savannah. The site had light industry (mostly tanning and shoe making) and houses for the workers. In the mid-1800s, the Central Railroad of Georgia started to dominate the area, constructing a Passenger Depot, cotton warehouse, and offices that front Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd.

Archaeology:

The 1984 archaeological investigation found the buried, former ground surface where people were living in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. Backhoes removed large amounts of recent soil, revealing a rock foundation, burned layer, and a rich midden zone (trash pits).

Archaeologists found differences between people living in the core of Savannah and here at the edge of town. The animal bones show Savannahians had a similar diet to other urbanites along the Southeastern coast, with a heavy emphasis on beef. However people in New Leeds were eating much more goat and sheep than their coastal, urban contemporaries. Historic research revealed that a number of bootmakers and tanners had lived in the site area. Archaeologists identified John Gardiner, a shoemaker and tanner, who owned his lot and lived on site. It is rare that archaeologists are able to directly connect an individual to the artifacts they leave behind!

site.name: Fort Stewart
site.desc: Fort Stewart (originally Camp Stewart) was created in June 1940, just before World War II on 5,000 acres southwest of Savannah, GA.
site.longDesc:
Time period: Late 1700s to 1900s

Type of site: Domestic, Industrial

History:

Fort Stewart (originally Camp Stewart) was created in June 1940, just before World War II on 5,000 acres southwest of Savannah, GA. Today Fort Stewart is over 280,000 acres. Named after Brigadier General Daniel Stewart, an American Revolutionary from Liberty County and the great grandfather of Theodore Roosevelt, Camp Stewart was used as a Nation Guard Training camp after World War II. Camp Stewart was renamed Fort Stewart and became a permanent military installation in 1956.

Archaeology:

The most significant prehistoric Native American site on Fort Stewart is Lewis Mound, an Indian burial mound, dating from 2200 to 1700 BC during the Late Archaic. This site was occupied occasionally through 1000 AD, during the Woodland Period. Native American would have stayed briefly to hunt or gather plants.

Lewis Mound itself was constructed around 1200 to 1300 AD to bury and commemorate a respected leader during the Savannah Period. Many similar Mississippian-era mounds were excavated in the 1930s in Chatham County. There are also three contemporary sites near Lewis Mound. This area was probably home to a chief and a seasonal home to the Native Americans practicing slash and burn cultivation from the late spring into the fall. During the winter and early spring, the group would move to the coast to fish and gather shellfish.

Georgia founder James Oglethorpe established a number of military outposts and settlements surrounding Savannah, including Fort Argyle, the first known European settlement on Fort Stewart. The fort was occupied sporadically until 1767. Archaeologists found evidence of the fort’s location including a palisade ditch, a moat, two corner bastions, and several buildings. Small gunflints and lead balls .60 caliber and smaller were found showing that Rangers guarding the fort were issued pistols and carbines rather than larger muskets like the British regulars.

Also on Fort Stewart is the 14-acre Taylors Creek Camp Ground, a Methodist camp meeting place from 1819 to 1941. The campground consisted of the Tabernacle, a large building for church services, surrounded by cabins with clay-lined hearths, chimneys, and a small kitchen in the rear. Recent excavations at Taylors Creek Campground found artifacts dating from 1800 to 1850.

See some of the recovered artifacts at the Fort Stewart Online Museum

site.name: Fort Jackson
site.desc: Fort Jackson sits next to Five Fathom Hole, a deep channel in the Savannah River where ships would wait for the high tide before traveling upriver to Savannah.
site.longDesc:
Time period: 1808-1905

Type of site: Military

History:

Forts, like real estate, are all about location. Fort Jackson sits next to Five Fathom Hole, a deep channel in the Savannah River where ships would wait for the high tide before traveling upriver to Savannah. Before Fort Jackson, a Revolutionary War mud battery was also located here on Salter’s Island, named for Thomas Salter who started a 1730s brickyard on the “island”, really a high spot in the marsh.

In 1808 Captain William McRee started work on Fort Jackson, named for Revolutionary War Brig. General James Jackson. Although McRee was only 19 years old, he was formally trained in military engineering. Low funding stopped work after the initial progress. But the impending War of 1812 forced the work to resume in the fall of 1811 with Captain McRee supervising a crew of leased slaves.

Once completed, newly formed militia groups, including the Chatham Artillery, Republican Blues, and the Savannah Heavy Artillery, as well as the 8th US Infantry, staffed the fort. Fortunately Fort Jackson did not see any action during the War of 1812, but it gave the soldiers a chance to test drive the new fort. They discovered the gun platform was too short and steep, which lead to the 1823-1835 improvements.

1847 through 1858 saw more improvements and updates to the fort using the latest technology: steam engines, cranes, steam pumps and pile drivers, asphaltum for water proofing, and prefabricated hinges and hardware. Workers added three brick barracks, the moat, the rear brick wall, and a large brick magazine. Captain Jeremy Gilmore, a West Point graduate, supervised the work during the cooler months. Warm weather meant mosquitoes, yellow fever, and malaria, and the army would head inland.

Fort Jackson was unmanned during the 1861 Confederate seizure. State troops held Fort Jackson in the cooler months, and during summers there was one guard who rotated daily. Civil War life at Fort Jackson was fairly dull until the night of December 20, 1864, when Savannah-based Confederate troops evacuated, and Sherman’s army prepared to enter the city. River battery troops gathered at Fort Jackson, crossed into South Carolina by steamer, and the ironclad CSS Georgia anchored off Fort Jackson was scuttled and sunk. Union troops entered Fort Jackson at 7am on December 21 and found the barracks and kitchen burned, the magazine booby trapped, and the guns spiked.

The United States Army made a half-hearted attempt to revive Fort Jackson in the 1870s, but the fort was obsolete. A caretaker lived in the casemates while the fort was used as a storage area, and it was officially closed in 1905. The Coastal Heritage Society (CHS) revived Fort Jackson and has managed the historic site since 1976. Note: Entry fees apply: http://chsgeorgia.org/Old-Fort-Jackson.html

Archaeology:

In 1969, the first archaeology at Fort Jackson focused on the lives of the soldiers. Archaeologists excavated inside the fort, including the privies. Today these artifacts are on display or stored in the museum, but they are also a cautionary tale. The artifacts’ context is lost because no report or field notes exist. Today archaeologists preserve (or curate) all notes, excavation forms, photographs, maps, reports, and other data with the artifacts in special facilities. This way the site’s information and history is not lost.

More recent archaeology has focused on understanding the fort’s construction to aid preservation efforts. Archaeologists examined the top of the Tide Tunnel, the brick arch extending into the river that allows water to flow through the moat with the tides. The Tide Tunnel had several severe cracks that needed repair. While archaeologists hoped to find the original soil placed on top of the brick arch, they only found modern artifacts, and the CHS masons repaired the Tide Tunnel.

Today modern concrete covers the gun platform and the casemates (arched rooms) beneath. These casemates are too wet, damaging the masonry. Archaeologists hoped to find a drainage system or an older surface beneath the concrete and were somewhat successful. While no drainage system was discovered, older floor surfaces were found. Packed earth and rubble were beneath a laid brick floor, which was covered in a paving material (possibly asphaltum). Archaeologists also discovered the cannon placements: an arch-shaped granite block where iron track was laid. Cannon carriages swung left to right on these tracks, allowing the cannon to aim. It was a wonderful surprise that so much of the original fort was preserved beneath the modern surface.

Some of the worst water damage to the casemates is under the 1870s powder magazine, so archaeologists excavated the soil covering the concrete roof. Few artifacts were found, but the archaeology revealed a bizarrely shaped roof that helped preservationists better understand the construction of the building. Working on top of the magazine proved fun but challenging. The height and angle of the roof turned archaeologists into mountain goats, but the views of downtown Savannah and the wildlife including dolphins, bald eagles, and a particularly close encounter with a brown pelican made it worthwhile.
site.evDesc: Early archaeology at Old Fort Jackson focused on soldiers’ lives. Soda water, liquor, beer, wine, and ginger beer bottles were found in the privies, or outhouses.
These cans likely once held food. Buckles and buttons are from clothing worn by soldiers.
Soil conditions in the privy were favorable for the preservation of organic material like cherry and peach pits, animal bones, oyster shell, and even the wood and bone handles on utensils.
The tide tunnel allows water to flow between the moat and river. Archaeology was conducted prior to Coastal Heritage Society (CHS) historic preservationists fixing large cracks in the brick arch.
CHS preservationists also asked archaeologists to examine the terreplein, or cannon platform. Fortunately, the modern surface covered older floors and features.
Beneath the modern terreplein was the half-circle stone base for the back wheels of the cannon carriage. An iron track would be laid on the stone. A second stone track has been removed (foreground).
Archaeologists also investigated the powder magazine roof to help preservationists better understand its construction.
Digging on the powder magazine’s roof required some creative new excavation techniques.

site.name: Fort Pulaski
site.desc: Named after Revolutionary War hero Casimir Pulaski, the current brick fort is actually the third fortification built on Cockspur Island, approximately 15 miles east of Savannah.
site.longDesc:
Time period: 1761-1900, Civil War

Type of site: Military, Industrial

History:

Named after Revolutionary War hero Casimir Pulaski, the current brick fort is actually the third fortification built on Cockspur Island, approximately 15 miles east of Savannah. William Gerard de Brahm built the first fort, a log blockhouse with palisade, in 1761. Fort George, named for the British king, was in ruins by 1774. In the same area, Fort Greene was built in 1790, only to be destroyed by a hurricane in 1804.

Fort Pulaski was part of the Third System of American Coastal Defense. Major Samuel Babcock of the Army Corps of Engineers oversaw initial construction in 1829, but Robert E. Lee, newly graduated from West Point quickly took over, as Babcock was ill. Lieutenant Joseph K.F. Mansfield oversaw the fort's construction from 1831 to 1845. To create a stable structure in the marsh, workers drove pilings 70 feet into the soft mud and sand. Brick arches support the 30 foot wide terreplein (cannon platform). Below, these 67 arched casemates were soldiers’ housing and storage.

After a period of relative inactivity, soldiers from the State militia took over the fort on January 3, 1861. Confederate soldiers holding the fort had little clue that Union troops were building 11 batteries on Tybee Island until April 10-11, 1862, when the mortars and rifled cannons opened fire. The Union forces breeched the southeast wall, and the Confederate Colonel Charles H. Olmstead surrendered. The new technology of rifled cannons allowed the Union troops to shoot farther and more accurately, making the attack from Tybee Island possible and effective, all while well out of range of Fort Pulaski’s cannons.

Union troops began to rebuild Fort Pulaski, although it was mostly used for storage and POW housing. Union soldiers organized a baseball team, a band, and a drama club. After the war, some renovations were completed, but Fort Pulaski was now outdated and by 1880 was no longer a military installation. Note: Fort Pulaski is a National Monument and entrance fees apply.

Archaeology:

So far, no Native American artifacts have been found on the grounds of Fort Pulaski National Monument. Nor have the locations of Fort George and Fort Greene been found, despite a search through 80 shovel tests in 1999.

Archaeologists investigating the April 1862 battle dug on Tybee Island, at the Union’s Battery Halleck. Archaeologists mapped the site, finding the east and west mortar platforms, the powder magazine and its loading room. Excavation test units did not reveal Civil War artifacts, although some heavily rusted metal artifacts were unidentified.

At Fort Pulaski, excavations have focused on finding burials, particularly the Immortal 600 (a group of Confederate POWs) and the construction worker’s camp. Cisterns and square brickworks can be seen above surface from the worker’s camp. Archaeologists have mapped these features and did some limited excavations. Coal, cinders, metal fragments, wooden planks with iron and copper nails, and brick fragments were recovered from one feature thought to be a fireplace or oven. Another test area revealed brick and mortar rubble, oyster shell, mammal and fish bones, nails and other metal fragments, glass, and historic ceramics. The excavation and historic map research combined to indicate this might be a stove or fireplace associated with the mechanics building.

The cemetery has received the most archaeological attention at Fort Pulaski. In 1999, archaeologists identified the extent of the cemetery, and 37 burials were identified. Burials lie both east/west and north/south. 19 (possibly 21) lie in the Confederate section. Archival research suggests most of the Union troops who died during the Civil War were exhumed. Seven graves, oriented north-south are likely civilians and post-Civil War military personnel.
site.evDesc: The demilune and the brickwork each have a sallyport, or guarded drawbridge entrance.
The cemetery at Fort Pulaski is delineated by a low brick wall.
Construction camp brickwork and cisterns can be seen around the fort.
Damage from the Union rifled cannons is obvious along the north wall of the fort.
The worst of the damage was repaired and is evident in the newer, brighter red brick.
Inside the fort: the parade ground is below and the terreplein, or upper cannon platform, surrounds all five sides.
Closer view of the terreplein: each brick platform held one cannon, which swung on the half-circle-shaped iron track to aim.

site.name: HAAF
site.desc: In September 1929, a municipal airport was opened on 730 acres that is now Hunter Army Airfield.
site.longDesc:
Time period: 500 BC - present

Type of site: Native American, Rural Farmsteads, Cemeteries

History:

This area was sparsely populated until the 1920s. In September 1929, a municipal airport was opened on 730 acres that is now Hunter Army Airfield. Dubbed the Savannah Airport in 1930, by 1932, it was already the Hunter Airfield/Savannah Airport. The Works Progress Administration built a hangar, three runways, and an administration building in 1935. After World War II, the base was briefly inactive but became a permanent base in 1950.

Archaeology:

Many people do not realize that archaeologists work on military bases! Section 109 of the National Historic Preservation Act states that all federal land must be surveyed for historic resources. Hunter Army Airfield and Fort Stewart have a combined team of archaeologists and preservationists.

The initial 1984 survey of Hunter Army Airfield found 2 prehistoric sites, 6 historic sites, and one site containing both prehistoric and historic component. Today, there are approximately 4,000 known sites on both “Hunter”, as the base is known locally, and Fort Stewart, Hunter’s larger neighbor. The initial 9 sites are representative of the types of sites found on the base: a Native American, Deptford Period (500 BC-700 AD) campsite, a Savannah Period (1000-1400 AD) shellfish gathering camp, and small rural farmsteads operated by tenant farmers (circa 1775-1850 AD).

Recently, archaeologists excavated two African American cemeteries eligible for listing on the National Register. Both cemeteries date from the 1880s to 1910s. Approximately 400 individuals were excavated, analyzed, and reburied with input from the local community. A full listing of cemeteries on Hunter and Fort Stewart are available here

site.name: Irene Mounds
site.desc: A six acre Native American agricultural site that has become part of the Georgia Port Authority
site.longDesc:
Time period: 1100-1600 AD (Mississippian Period)

Type of site: Native American

History:

This site was occupied during the Mississippian Period, a complex time when chiefdoms ruled across the Southeast, and large scale agriculture supported large populations. Irene Mound was located on the Savannah River, approximately five miles west of Savannah, just south of the junction with Pipemaker’s Creek. The six acre site was an island at high tide. The mound was occupied until 1600 AD. In 1736, a Moravian Mission School was built on the summit of the deserted mound. Today the site is completely destroyed, and the land is part of Georgia Ports Authority.

Archaeology:

The Irene Mounds site was thoroughly excavated by the Works Progress Administration in the late 1930s. The Irene site helped these early archaeologists create a ceramic chronology, or understanding of what types of pottery were made and when, and how they were decorated.

Archaeologists found a large rectangular, flat-topped temple mound; a small, conical burial mound; shell middens; and other buildings at ground level. The site also included a series of concentric circular walls called a rotunda, which was a public meeting space. The Irene site was where a Chief lived with his family and “support staff”. Other families living and farming in the area would have visited the Irene site for social, governmental, and ceremonial reasons.

site.name: Jewish Cemeteries
site.desc: The site of Fort Prevost and Fort Wayne due to strategic position over the Savannah River
site.longDesc:
Time period: early 1700s, American Revolution

Type of site: Cemetery, Military

History:

Five months after James Oglethorpe founded Savannah, the first Jewish colonists arrived in Georgia. Amongst these colonists was a doctor, Samuel Nunes, whose help was invaluable later during a yellow fever epidemic.

The smaller Jewish Cemetery is the Levi Sheftall family plot, which was in use by 1765. The larger Jewish Cemetery, approximately 180 feet to the south, was created in 1770 by Mordecai Sheftall, Levi’s older half brother, who donated 1.5 acres of his garden lot for use as community cemetery.

During the 1779 Battle of Spring Hill, the Haitian reserve troops waited at the Jewish Cemeteries (south of Spring Hill Redoubt and outside of town). As the Americans and their allies retreated in chaos, the Haitian reserve proved invaluable, and the British did not pursue the retreating rebels.

After the war, this area was developed, extensively so in the later 1800s. Housing, railroad development, and a large cotton mill were located directly west of the cemeteries.

Archaeology:

The Levi Sheftall Cemetery was the subject of archaeological investigation in 1990. No graves were excavated, but accumulated soil around the headstones was excavated, and the cemetery was mapped. Lots of children’s marbles were found as well as bullets. The bullets ranged from 18th century lead musket balls to a modern .45 caliber automatic.

Today the cemeteries sit behind Esther Garrison Elementary School. Heavy excavation equipment was used in constructing the school and surrounding playgrounds. Archaeologists working in 2010 found that these areas have been scraped clean of archaeological evidence. Areas of higher elevation did have soil layers from the domestic and industrial period after the 1779 Battle of Savannah. Archaeologists also interviewed several relic collectors who collected artifacts during the school’s construction. They found extensive Revolutionary War-era materials including cannon balls, lead balls (bullets), and gunflints.

Archaeologists believe (and hope!) the high elevation areas may still contain a very deeply buried Revolutionary War layer, which could tell the Haitian Reserve soldier’s story. However, much of the site has been destroyed.

site.name: Lafayette Square
site.desc: Historical maps suggest this is the location of the East-Central redoubt
site.longDesc:
Time period: American Revolution

Type of site: Military

History:

During the American Revolution, this area was outside of the city. Lafayette Square and the surrounding ward were not developed until the 1840s and 1850s.

Archaeology:

Historic map analysis suggested that the East-Central Redoubt was located in Lafayette Square, so archaeologists conducted a ground penetrating radar survey and dug several test pits (holes) in the northwest quadrant of the square. Archaeologists found many artifacts from the 1730s to 1770s including a .28 caliber lead ball, some gunflint fragments, and ceramics. Since this area was outside of the town during the Revolutionary War, it is likely these artifacts were used by the soldiers or workers(likely slaves) building the fortifications. Another possibility is that citizens were camped here to avoid the Allies’ bombing.

Later trash deposits were found above the 1700s material and were likely left behind during the completion of War of 1812 defenses and later construction of houses as the town encroached in the 1840s and 1850s. Several Catholic religious medals were lost over the years as well.

site.name: Laurel Grove Cemetery
site.desc: Dedicated in 1852, Laurel Grove Cemetery was established to replace the old Colonial Cemetery, which was desperately full.
site.longDesc:
Time period: 1850s to present

Type of site: Cemetery

History:

Laurel Grove Cemetery was created out of Springfield Plantation, first established by a Loyalist, Lachlan McGillivray, before 1760. McGillivray returned to Scotland in 1770, abandoning the plantation. Joseph Clay purchased the property in 1782, and his heirs eventually sold 960 acres to the city, 100 of which became Laurel Grove Cemetery. Dedicated in 1852, Laurel Grove Cemetery was established to replace the old Colonial Cemetery, which was desperately full.

Archaeology:

Laurel Grove Cemetery was archaeologically investigated as part of the Savannah Under Fire project. While searching for the 1779 American and French siege camps, archaeologists did ground penetrating radar surveys. Using this data, they conducted a limited shovel test survey in areas confirmed not to have graves. Shovel testing near the Anderson Street entrance did reveal artifacts from the late 1700s through mid-1800s, which are probably from Springfield Plantation residents. However, no evidence of the Revolutionaries’ camps was found.

site.name: Madison Square
site.desc: Location of a military ditch dug by British forces in 1779 identified as the West-Central redoubt.
site.longDesc:
Time period: American Revolution

Type of site: Military

History:

Bull Street is one of the first streets in Savannah, bisecting the city north/south. During the American Revolution, this area was the location of two Central Redoubts (small forts) and just inside the fortification was a brick barracks. Shortly before the 1779 battle, the barracks were torn down and the bricks were used to reinforce the fortifications. Sgt. William Jasper’s monument stands in the middle of Madison Square. Sgt. Jasper is pictured just after he climbed the Spring Hill Redoubt and planted the 2nd South Carolina Regiment company’s flag. Notice he is grasping his side. He died that day from his wounds.

Archaeology:

In 2008, archaeologists discovered a military ditch dug by British forces in 1779. Angling northwest-southeast, this ditch was identified as part of the West-Central redoubt, which was the location of Allies’ feint before real attack at Spring Hill at dawn October 9, 1779.

After the British left Savannah in the summer of 1782, the Americans filled in the ditches, burying many artifacts as well. Brick from the barracks was also found in the ditch. Many of these artifacts tell us about the lives of the soldiers, including how they spent their free time.

site.name: Owens Thomas House
site.desc: A lot with rich history and many archaeological digs that is currently a part of the Telfair Academy
site.longDesc:
Time period: 1700s to present

Type of site: Domestic

History:

Royal surveyor William DeBraham built his 1760 house on the lot currently occupied by the Owens-Thomas House. In 1816, Richard Richardson bought the lot and hired architect William Jay build the existing house, carriage house, and slave quarters. Richardson sold the house in 1822, and Mary Maxwell operated a boarding house for several years, entertaining guests such as the Marquis de Lafayette during his 1825 American tour. George Welschman Owens bought the property in 1830, and it remained with his heirs until 1951, when the family donated it to the Telfair Academy.

Archaeology:

Many archaeological digs have taken place at the Owens-Thomas House. Starting in 1965, J. Everette Fauber dug in the southwest basement rooms. Staff were told Boy Scouts dug on the property at one time, but, if so, there is no documentation and no artifacts were saved. The Coastal Georgia Archaeological Society dug approximately 300 square feet, finding artifacts from the 1700s DeBraham occupation.

The Chicora Foundation’s 1993 excavation was focused on the architecture of the carriage house and slave quarters and the nature of urban slave life. The archaeologists found surprisingly many clothing and personal items, showing that slaves had access to more material goods and suggesting urban slaves had more control over their lives than rural slaves. Archaeologists also found many plates, rather than bowls. Bowls are often found on slaves sites because slaves usually made slow-cooking soups and stews that can be started in the morning and simmered all day, breaking down poor, tough cuts of meat. The presence of more plates may suggest a diet of less soups and more "meat-and sides". Archaeologists could not determine if the plates were purchased by the slaves or were hand-me-downs from the main house.

Note: The Owens-Thomas House is a museum open to the public. Fees apply for entry and tours.
site.evDesc: The carriage house and slave quarters for the Owens-Thomas House.

The southern side of the Owens-Thomas House. The white, cast-iron balcony is where the Marquis de Lafayette gave a speech during his tour of America in 1825. The Marquis de Lafayette was a general and important French ally during in the American Revolution.

site.name: Railroad Ward
site.desc: The Railroad Ward is bounded by MLK Jr. Boulevard and West Harris, Purse, and Charlton streets. From the 1830s, the ward held small houses often owned or rented by people working at the adjacent Central of Georgia and their families.
site.longDesc:
Time period: 1830s-present

Type of site: Domestic

History:

Savannah is a carefully designed city, divided up into wards. Each ward consists of a central square surrounded by 4 tythings (or 40 town lots) and four Trust Lots for the public good, which often held public buildings. The earliest white, male settlers received a town lot (60x90 ft), a farm south of town (44 acres) and a garden lot west of town (5 acres).

The Railroad Ward is bounded by MLK Jr. Boulevard and West Harris, Purse, and Charlton streets. From the 1830s, the ward held small houses often owned or rented by people working at the adjacent Central of Georgia and their families.

Archaeology:

Prior to the construction to the Marriott Hotel, archaeologists were able to excavate part of the hotel’s footprint. Many of the residents left behind items from their everyday lives such as toys, plates, bowls, tea pots, bathroom tiles, buttons, and animal bones from their dinners. The current Marriott Hotel “cottages” are made to resemble the original Railroad Ward houses.

site.name: Railroad Ward House
site.desc: Prior to its development as the Railroad Ward, this area was part of Garden Lots 9 and 10, as established by James Oglethorpe, founder of Georgia.
site.longDesc:
Time period: 1830 to present

Type of site: Domestic

History:

Prior to its development as the Railroad Ward, this area was part of Garden Lots 9 and 10, as established by James Oglethorpe, founder of Georgia. Each of the original settlers received a town lot on which to build a home, a garden lot for producing food on the outskirts of town, and an outlying farm lot of 45 acres.

In the early 1880s, several factors led to a big expansion of the Railroad Ward’s residential section. The post-Reconstruction economy was finally booming, and the railroad was doing well financially. An 1883 fire devastated the nearby Yamacraw Ward, and many of its residents relocated to the Railroad Ward. There is very little historical information available on the Railroad Ward residents, making the archaeology invaluable.

Archaeology:

In 2008, Coastal Heritage Society purchased the two of the remaining original houses in Savannah’s Railroad Ward to prevent their demolition. As part of the purchase agreement, one house was moved to an adjacent lot. Prior to the move, archaeologists excavated small, backyard trash pits and one privy, or outhouse, all dating to the late nineteenth and early twentieth century when the neighborhood was mostly working class families, including Central of Georgia employees.

The excellent faunal preservation hints at a varied diet; egg shells, animal bones, fish bones, oyster shells, and crab shells were all found. There is ample evidence for children living here: slate pencils, ceramic and glass marbles, toy jacks, a child’s ring, and a miniature porcelain teapot were discovered.

It is the personal artifacts found on this site that most speak to the people’s lives. Archaeologists recovered many clothing and personal grooming artifacts (buckles; a hook from a hook and eye; clothing rivets; part of a shoe heel; a pocketknife; and buttons made of porcelain, bone, shell, rubber, glass, and metal). Fragments of Bakelite combs and a jar that contained Dixie Peach Hair Pomade show how these residents liked to style their hair. Several fragments of mirror glass in different thicknesses were also found. A round pendant, probably from a necklace, and many tobacco pipe fragments were uncovered. Only one bottle was identifiable as a medicine bottle, embossed with Masonic Temple Pharmacy in Savannah.

site.name: Riverfront Hotel
site.desc: A shipyard, cotton press and warehouse, saw mill, and iron foundry are some of the businesses that operated here.
site.longDesc:
Time period: 1830s-1930s

Type of site: Industrial

History:

In the 1830s and 1840s, Savannah’s eastern riverfront was developed into wharves and a bustling commercial area. A shipyard, cotton press and warehouse, saw mill, and iron foundry are some of the businesses that operated here. In the late 1880s, the railroads connected to the area allowing for greater volume of commerce.

Archaeology:

Prior to the hotel construction, archaeology was conducted. Circa World War I-era shipways and a dock were found as well as a late 1920s/early 1930s vessel. The vessel was possibly a large harbor tug. The finds were under a great deal of modern fill, and although much archaeological material was found, nothing “significant”, or eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, was found.

site.name: Skidaway State Park
site.desc: A beautiful state park with a long history well before Savannah's time
site.longDesc:
Time period: Late Archaic Period (4,500-3,000 years ago), 1749- Civil War

Type of site: Native American, Military, Plantation

History:

During the Late Archaic Period (4,500-3,000 years ago), small bands Native Americans camped seasonally along the Georgia coast, gathering shellfish and other marine resources. Large shell middens, or trash piles filled with shells, are one of the most common prehistoric archaeological sites along our coast. During this period, the first pottery appears, and the transition begins from a hunter-gatherer lifestyle to a more settled life of growing food in village gardens.

After colonization, Richard Palmer began the 500 acre Springfield Plantation in 1749. The plantation passed through many hands until February 1858 when William Ziegler bought the property for $10,000, plus paid $15,000 for 31 slaves. Ziegler died in 1862, but his estate did not sell the plantation until 1874. According to the historical record, cotton and livestock were produced on the plantation. It is also likely that rice and indigo were grown as they were on other Skidaway Island plantations.

The Skidaway batteries, built by the Chatham Artillery, were part of an organized defensive line from Savannah to Florida. In 1861 about 800 men worked to construct batteries across the island to pacify plantation owners concerned about a Union invasion. Union ships patrolled the area, keeping the Confederates occupied with that very concern. But the batteries were inaccessible, and the Confederates evacuated Skidaway Island in March 1862. The Union army took over Skidaway Island shortly after and held the island for the rest of the war.

Archaeology:

Part of Springfield Plantation was the subject of an archaeological study prior to Skidaway Island State Park acquiring the tract near its northern border. Archaeologists conducted a systematic metal detector survey, mapping each artifact found. They also did a topographic survey, creating an elevation map of the area. Archaeologists found a linear row of ruined brick and tabby foundations, which were probably the slave quarters. They excavated a five by ten foot area to sample the plantation’s midden (trash pit).

Midden excavations uncovered late 1700s and early 1800s era ceramics, animal bones, wine bottle glass, tobacco pipe fragments, buttons, a fishing weight, handmade nails, and a cast iron “bean pot”. Bricks and tabby, a building material similar to concrete, were also found with some Native American ceramics and a projectile point (arrowhead). While the English materials were probably being used by the colonists and slaves, the Native American artifacts were probably mixed in when colonists pulled shell from shell middens to make tabby (a mix of lime, sand, oyster shell, and water). The lime comes from burning oyster shell to create lime and ash.

A portion of the Civil War earthworks were also mapped. The earthwork is a complicated road and earthwork that probably dates prior to the Civil War. Archaeologists hypothesized this may have originally been a saltwater intrusion barrier to prevent the marsh saltwater from entering the plantation’s rice and indigo fields. Civil War soldiers would have added on to the existing structure to create their battery.

site.name: The Marriott and Liberty Garage
site.desc: The tragedy of destroying historic dig sites
site.longDesc:
Time period: Late 1700s-1800s

Type of site: Domestic

History:

Most archaeological sites in the United States do not have any legal protection. However, for projects conducted on federal land or projects using federal permits or funding, the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 (NHPA) requires an archaeological survey to be conducted. If important archaeological sites are found, they are either preserved or (more likely) excavated to recover the data contained in the site. The NHPA covers very few of the development projects in the United States.

Archaeology:

At the southeast corner of Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd and Liberty Street, two projects were conducted under the NHPA. A small brick cellar dating to the earliest decades of the 19 th century was identified prior to the construction of the Marriott hotel.

A late-18th and 19th century site was found before the Liberty Street Parking Garage was built. This site was designated 9Ch696. The 9 is for Georgia, Ch for Chatham County, and it is the 696 archaeological site recorded in Chatham County. The 19th century features and building ruins were considered eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, which was created by the NHPA of 1966.
site.evDesc: The Liberty Street Parking Garage is next to the Marriott on Liberty Street. Enormous buildings like hotels and parking garages require massive earth moving during construction, which destroys archaeology sites.

site.name: Tybee Island Lighthouse
site.desc: James Oglethorpe chose this spot for a navigational marker in 1733, the same year he founded Georgia. A lighthouse has stood in this area ever since.
site.longDesc:
Time period: 1733 to present

Type of site: Domestic, Maritime

History:

James Oglethorpe chose this spot for a navigational marker in 1733, the same year he founded Georgia. A lighthouse has stood in this area ever since. By 1736 Noble Jones, Georgia’s surveyor, supervised the construction of a 90 foot wooden tower, although it did not have a light. This daytime navigation maker was the largest on the British-controlled east coast. In 1741, a storm destroyed the tower.

A second, 90-94 foot lighthouse was built by 1742. It too did not have a light. An associated Keeper’s House was also built nearby. This lighthouse was gone by 1768, a victim of the harsh coastal elements. The third lighthouse was built in 1773 and destroyed by fire in 1791. The current lighthouse, a 100 foot, octagonal-base brick lighthouse, was built in 1791, probably on the foundation of the 1773 building. Note: the Tybee Light is a museum today; entry fees apply.

Archaeology:

The Assistant Keeper’s House was restored in 2003. Since the restoration included some ground-disturbing activities, the Tybee Island Historical Society, which runs the Light Station and the Tybee Museum, called in archaeologists to make sure they weren’t destroying historic resources.

Archaeologists examined two corners the brick foundation beneath the existing, circa 1885 house. They excavated two test units (square areas that were dug out), finding nearly 5,000 artifacts in their small excavation. Artifacts recovered included architectural materials like brick, mortar, and window glass; kitchen ceramics, bottle glass, and tin cans were also discovered. Food remains showed the dietary variety: turtle, beef, pork, foul, fish, and eggs were eaten on site. Shellfish were also an important part of the diet including oysters, clams, crab, and whelk. Personal artifacts were found as well: a brass finger ring, pocketknife fragments, a glass marble, mirror glass, newspaper scraps, matches, and a piece of engraved slate. Bullets and other armament artifacts were found as well as uniform buckles and a brass insignia. Many of these are probably from the Civil War soldiers camped near the lighthouse.

The brick foundation under the current house is the footing for an earlier keeper’s house. A brown transfer printed sherd (ceramic fragment) was found in the foundation’s builder’s trench. Brown transfer printed ceramics were first made in 1809, so the building must date after 1809. The historical record states this circa 1809 house burned in 1885. Melted window and bottle glass were found with exploded bricks and highly tempered (heat-treated) nails. When iron is heated to extremely high temperatures, the nails are preserved and rust-free.

Artifacts from the 1700s were also found, so an even earlier building was also probably on this site. While no structural remains were found for an earlier building, an undated brick hearth and chimney pad were found, possibly from this 1700s era building.
site.evDesc: The current assistant keeper’s house was built in 1885. Archaeologists excavated under two corners of this house during recent renovations. This building is office space and is not open to the public.
The current lighthouse complex includes the head keeper’s house, two assistant keepers’ houses, and a summer kitchen in addition to the lighthouse.

site.name: Wormsloe
site.desc: Wormsloe is best known as Noble Jones’ 500 acre colonial plantation on the Isle of Hope, but Native American occupied the area long before colonization.
site.longDesc:
Time period: Native American, Colonial, Civil War

Type of site: Domestic, Military

History:

Wormsloe is best known as Noble Jones’ 500 acre colonial plantation on the Isle of Hope, but Native American occupied the area long before colonization. Creek Indians lived along the coast during the Mississippian Period (1,100-500 years before present) taking advantage of the delicious, rich coastal resources such as oyster and crabs.

A doctor, carpenter, and surveyor, Noble Jones (1702-1775) was among the Georgia colonists who arrived with James Oglethorpe, the founder of Georgia. Jones played many roles in Georgia’s early history including constable, surveyor, soldier, Royal Councilor, Justice of the Province, and more. Jones’ son, Noble W. Jones, was a member of the Second Continental Congress and the Georgia House of Assembly.

On his plantation, Wormsloe, Jones had corn, potatoes, rice, oranges, figs, peaches, and mulberry trees (for silk worms), as well as cattle. The house complex was started in 1737 and took six years to build. The five-room, 1 ½ story house was large for its time, but tiny by today’s standards. Eight-foot high walls surrounded the house and courtyard area with bastions (diamond-shaped points) at each corner. The walls were meant to protect the family from the Spanish during the War of Jenkins’ Ear (1739-1748). A separate cellar and water well were also in the enclosure.

Noble Jones’ descendants still live on 80 acres of the original plantation. In 1972 the family donated 822 acres to the Nature Conservancy, who sold the land the next year to the State of Georgia. Note: Wormsloe Historic Site is a Georgia State Park. Fees for entry apply.

Archaeology:

Shell middens from the Savannah and Irene periods of Native American history are present at Wormsloe. These are Mississippian era sites (1,100-500 years before present). Shell middens are common in coastal areas and are essentially trash mounds from early oyster roasts.

The remnants of Noble Jones’ tabby plantation house were excavated in 1969. Tabby is a building material used like concrete. The mix of lime, sand, oyster shell, and water is poured into molds and hardened. The lime comes from burning oyster shell to create lime and ash. Shell for making tabby was often harvested from nearby Native American shell middens. Today, you can visit the ruined house compound and defensive wall. Artifacts from the 1969 dig are on display in the on-site museum.

South of Jones’ plantation house, the Civil War earthwork Battery Wimberly (or Wymberley) overlooks the Moon River. Battery Wimberly was built in two stages, 1862-1863 and 1864. When mapped and surveyed in the early 1990s, parapets, traverses, and terrepleins were still present. A well was also found. Archaeologist Larry Babits described the battery as some of “the finest extant remaining examples of Confederate earthen fortifications”.
